skills.name: Identify unit fractions when part of a shape
Divide a proper fraction by an integer using a bar model

explanations.A: 1 means 1 whole. What fraction is the question mark pointing to?
explanations.B: The ? is a fifth of the shaded section, but how much is it of the whole?
explanations.C: The whole bar is split into 6 equal pieces. The question mark represents 1 piece. Therefore it is 1/6 of the whole.
explanations.D: 5/6 is just less than 1, but 6/5 is bigger than 1. Is this section bigger than 5/6?

explanations.A: 4/5 is just less than 1, but 5/4 is bigger than 1. Is this section bigger than 4/5?
explanations.B: The whole bar is split into 5 equal pieces. The question mark represents 1 piece. Therefore it is 1/5 of the whole.
explanations.C: The ? is a quarter of the shaded section, but how much is it of the whole?
explanations.D: 1 means 1 whole. What fraction is the question mark pointing to?

explanations.A: Look carefully. We are finding the shaded section. The entire section is marked ½ and it appears the green section takes up ½ of that. Which calculation describes that?
explanations.B: I think you may have gotten confused by the number of pieces. We want to focus on the marked area and the green section. Which calculation describes this location?
explanations.C: Careful! Dividing in half is not the same as dividing by half. If we divide by ½, we need to multiply by the reciprocal, which means we are timesing by 2. Is that what this image is showing?
explanations.D: The green section is ½ of the section that is marked ½. ½ x ½ is equivalent to ½ ÷ 2.

explanations.A: Careful! Dividing in half is not the same as dividing by half. If we divide by ½, we need to multiply by the reciprocal, which means we are timesing by 2. Is that what this image is showing?
explanations.B: Look carefully. We are finding the shaded section. The entire section is marked ⅓ and it appears the pink section takes up ½ of that. Which calculation describes that?
explanations.C: The pink section is ½ of the section that is marked ⅓. ⅓ x ½ is equivalent to ⅓ ÷ 2.
explanations.D: I think you may have gotten confused by the number of pieces. We want to focus on the marked area and the pink section. Which calculation describes this location?

explanations.A: Look carefully. We are finding the shaded section. The entire section is marked ³/₅ and it appears the blue section takes up ½ of that. Which calculation describes that?
explanations.B: I think you may have gotten confused by the number of pieces. We want to focus on the marked area and the blue section. Which calculation describes this location?
explanations.C: The blue section is ½ of the section that is marked ³/₅ . ³/₅ x ½ is equivalent to ³/₅ ÷ 2.
explanations.D: Careful! Dividing in half is not the same as dividing by half. If we divide by ½, we need to multiply by the reciprocal, which means we are timesing by 2. Is that what this image is showing?

explanations.A: I think you may have gotten confused by the number of pieces. We want to focus on the marked area and the pink section. Which calculation describes this location?
explanations.B: Careful! Dividing in half is not the same as dividing by half. If we divide by ½, we need to multiply by the reciprocal, which means we are timesing by 2. Is that what this image is showing?
explanations.C: Look carefully. We are finding the shaded section. The entire section is marked ⁵/₈ and it appears the pink section takes up ½ of that. Which calculation describes that?
explanations.D: The pink section is ½ of the section that is marked ⁵/₈ . ⁵/₈ x ½ is equivalent to ⁵/₈ ÷ 2.

explanations.A: I think you created a fraction of shaded squares compared to unshaded squares. In this case, we want to look at shaded squares compared to total squares. What would that fraction be?
explanations.B: It seems as if you multiplied ³/₅ by 2, but if you look at the bar model, how many blue squares do you see? How many equal-sized squares has the model been split into? How can we use these values to write a fraction?
explanations.C: I think you may have only focused on the ³/₅ marked section, but we want to focus on the entire model. How many blue squares do you see? How many equal-sized squares has the model been split into? How can we use these values to write a fraction?
explanations.D: We can see that the model has been split into 10 equal pieces. 3 of the pieces are shaded blue. Therefore, ³/₅ ÷ 2 = ³/₁₀

explanations.A: We can see that the model has been split into 16 equal pieces. 5 of the pieces are shaded blue. Therefore, ⁵/₈ ÷ 2 = ⁵/₁₆
explanations.B: I think you created a fraction of shaded squares compared to unshaded squares. In this case, we want to look at shaded squares compared to total squares. What would that fraction be?
explanations.C: I think you may have only focused on the ⁵/₈ marked section, but we want to focus on the entire model. How many blue squares do you see? How many equal-sized squares has the model been split into? How can we use these values to write a fraction?
explanations.D: It seems as if you multiplied ⁵/₈ by 2, but if you look at the bar model, how many blue squares do you see? How many equal-sized squares has the model been split into? How can we use these values to write a fraction?

explanations.A: It seems as if you multiplied ²/₃ by 5. Imagine splitting the model vertically into 3 equal sections. Then splitting ²/₃ into 5 equal sections horizontally and shading 1 of the 5 sections. How many sections would be shaded? How can we use this value to write a fraction?
explanations.B: The model was split vertically into 3 equal sections. Then ²/₃ of the model was split into 5 equal sections horizontally. Shading 1 of the 5 sections is equivalent to ²/₁₅.
explanations.C: I think you may have focused only on the ²/₃ portion of the model when counting total sections, but we need to look at the entire model. There are 15 equal-sized sections, not 10. How will that change your answer?
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you multiplied your numerator and your denominator by 5. Imagine splitting the model vertically into 3 equal sections. Then splitting ²/₃ into 5 equal sections horizontally and shading 1 of the 5 sections. How many sections would be shaded? How can we use this value to write a fraction?

explanations.A: I think you may have focused only on the ³/₅ portion of the model when counting total sections, but we need to look at the entire model. There are 20 equal-sized sections, not 12. How will that change your answer?
explanations.B: It seems as if you multiplied ³/₅ by 4. Imagine splitting the model vertically into 5 equal sections. Then splitting ³/₅ into 4 equal sections horizontally and shading 1 of the 4 sections. How many sections would be shaded? How can we use this value to write a fraction?
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you multiplied your numerator and your denominator by 4. Imagine splitting the model vertically into 5 equal sections. Then splitting ³/₅ into 4 equal sections horizontally and shading 1 of the 4 sections. How many sections would be shaded? How can we use this value to write a fraction?
explanations.D: The model was split vertically into 5 equal sections. Then ³/₅ of the model was split into 4 equal sections horizontally. Shading 1 of the 4 sections is equivalent to ³/₂₀.
